How-to_ GitHub.txt:
Slides references: 



W1M2 Marketing and Auton: GitHub

W2M2 Auton: Python





GITHUB





How to Clone a Repository - SSH



Navigate to the GitHub page of the repository you want to clone and locate the green “<> Code” button

Click on the SSH tab

Copy the SSH url

Go to your laptop’s terminal

“git clone [ssh_url]”





How to Pull Code From Main Branch



To pull code from the main branch when you already have changes locally:

Stash Your Changes: If you have local changes that you want to save for later, use git stash to temporarily store them.

Pull the Latest Code from the Main Branch:

“git pull origin main”

Apply Your Stashed Changes: Once the latest code is pulled, you can reapply your changes by using 

“git stash pop”

Alternatively, if you want to merge your changes with the latest code without stashing, you can use: 

“git pull --rebase origin main”

This will apply your changes on top of the updated main branch, reducing the likelihood of merge conflicts.





How to Commit Code to Local Repository



After making changes, stage your changes for commit using 

“git add <filename> or git add .” (to add all changes) 

Then, commit with a descriptive message:

 “git commit -m "your descriptive message"

Remember to always write **clear and concise** commit messages that describe the change in the code.



Note: “git commit -a -m "your descriptive message" combines “git add .” and “git commit -m "your descriptive message"





How to Resolve Merge Conflicts 



Git cannot resolve differences between two separate commits.



Types of Merge Conflicts:

Edit Conflict

Delete-Edit Conflict 

Content Conflict



You can resolve merge conflicts by:

Editing the file

Stashing changes

git stash

git pull

git stash pop

Merge editor

Add files and commit the change



For more reference: resolve merge conflicts





How to Use Branches



*Branches allow you to work on new features or bug fixes separately from the main codebase. 



Always create a new branch for each feature or fix

“git branch <new-branch-name>”

“git checkout -b <new-branch-name>”

“git switch -c <new-branch-name>”



Once the work is complete, merge it back to the main branch.

“git checkout main”

“git merge <completed-branch-name>”



Note: To keep the branches organized, you should always delete a branch once you finished implementing a feature and undergo code review, or successfully implement and fully test a fix to a bug



How to Delete a Branch



Locally: 

git branch -d <branch-name> safe delete 

git branch -D <branch-name> force delete



Remotely:

git push origin --delete <branch-name>



How to Switch to Existing Branches



“git switch <existing-branch>”

“git checkout <existing branch>”











GOOD CODING PRACTICES





Naming Conventions



Here are the criteria that make a good commit message:

The first line is less than 50 characters, with the first one capitalized. The words complete the sentence "If you pulled this commit into your own copy of the repo, this commit would..." You are informing the reader what value they are getting from your commit.

The second line is blank.

The remaining lines supply details.



Variables: snake_case

Functions: snake_case()

Classes: PascalCase

Constants: ALL_CAPS





Always Work in GitHub Branches How-to: Code & GitHub



*Avoid working directly in the main branch. Create a new branch for each task, allowing others to review changes before merging into the main codebase.





Update README.md Often 



*The README.md should provide an overview of the project, setup instructions, and any relevant information on usage. Keep it updated, especially when new features are added.





GitHub Pull Before Pushing How-to: Code & GitHub



*Always run git pull before pushing changes to ensure your local code is up-to-date with the remote repository. This helps prevent conflicts and potential merge conflicts.





Classes



Use classes to encapsulate related functions and data, especially for larger projects. Each class should have a single responsibility.





Global Constants/Variables



Global Constants and variables are values defined at the top of a file. We should use them because it makes it easier to modify values and results in cleaner code. We should use them anytime we have to hardcode a value





Environments



An environment is a directory containing a collection of software tools and installed packages. The benefit of using environments is it would prevent package collision errors. Install Conda → environment management system



venv commands:

python -m venv <directory>

source <directory>/bin/activate | venv\Scripts\Activate.ps1

deactivate

rm -r <directory>



Conda Commands: 

conda create --name <environment name>

conda activate <environment name>

conda deactivate

conda env list

Lists all of your environments

conda list

See which packages are installed in your current environment

Use pip to install python packages once you’re on your environment





Setup.sh



A setup script (setup.sh) can automate the setup process, installing necessary packages and configuring the environment. Use this to streamline the project setup for new contributors.





.gitignore



The “.gitignore” file specifies files and directories that should not be tracked by Git (e.g., sensitive data, large binary files, and local configuration files). Be sure to keep it updated.





Requirements.txt



A requirements.txt file lists all necessary packages for a Python project.











GIT COMMAND CHEAT SHEET



git status →  lists your branch, commit status, and more

git pull →  pulls from main

git add <filename> / git add -A / git add . → adds changes to staging area

git commit -m “commit message” → commits things in staging area locally

git push → pushed local commit to global repository

git checkout <branch name> [git checkout main, git checkout test_code] → switches branch

git branch <new branch name> → creates new branch

git help →  Gives a list of useful git commands

git restore <file> → Reverts changes and “restores” previous version of the file(s)

git rm <file> → Removes file from the working directory. Calling git add, git commit, git push will push the current working directory and remove file from the repo.

git stash → Stashes changes away (can be recovered), and provides a clean working directory.

git stash pop → Pops most recent stash back into the working directory
How-To_ Prototype Belt Lengths.txt:
How To Prototype Belt Lengths

Why should we prototype? 

While CAD is a very useful tool to model dimensions and positions of most things, belts are tricky because they have variable tension. In order to model this tension, we need to manually use trial and error before we can order any component which has belt axle holes in them. 

Setup:

You will firstly want to make sure you’ve ordered the belts you intend to use, the axles around which the belt will rotate, and any other component which is integral to the structure of the belt system, like bearings, wheels, shafts, or motors. 

The goal with this is to make sure your trial and error system is as close to your final product as possible, so as to better replicate the tension in the actual system.

You will additionally want continued access to a 3D printer, and PA6-CF or other similarly rigid filament.

Prototyping:

First, 3D print the upright as you have designed it in CAD based on the theoretical length and diameter of the belt.

Of course, this will not be accurate the first time, but rather to use as a reference point for whether to adjust the axles further or closer.

Assemble your system using the 3D printed upright, and use the tension in the belt in this setup to determine whether to increase tension by moving the axles further apart, or decrease tension, by moving them closer together.

If unsure, repeat the below steps for both larger and smaller increments.

Model an Isaac Arc™, similar to the one pictured below. The objective is to create an array of distances between the two axles in as small of a 3D printed object as possible, to save printing time and filament.

Laser Cutting/Water Jetting

Information

	Laser cutting and water jetting are two ways to cut 2D parts, as opposed to the 3 axes of a CNC machine. Both these methods functionally have the same purpose in combat robotics, but there are slight differences between the two. Laser cutting is more precise than water jetting, as the minimum cut size for a laser cutter is .15mm, while a waterjet has a minimum cutting slit size of .5mm. However, laser cutters are typically only able to cut materials up to around 35mm thick, while a waterjet can cut through parts as thick as 300mm. Additionally, waterjet cutting is more flexible and can cut a wider range of materials, while laser cutting excels at cutting materials (including but not limited to) glass, metal, wood, and plastic but cannot cut reflective materials due to cutting via heat.

How-To_ Make a DXF.txt:
How to make a DXF



A DXF file (Drawing Exchange Format file) is a vector file that’s used to share drawing data between different applications. A DXF file is needed for the following 2D manufacturing methods: 

Laser cutting

Water jetting

For more information on 2D manufacturing, see How-To: Design for different manufacturing methods. 



How to make a DXF file in Fusion

Let’s say I have this part that I would like to get manufactured from SendCutSend: 





Make a projected sketch

Click on the face that the laser (or water jet) will be cutting into (i.e. the face with the important geometry). 



Hit ‘Create Sketch’. 

Hit ‘P’ on your keyboard to activate the ‘Project’ feature. 

Click on the same face you selected before and hit ‘OK’. 

You should see a sketch of the face in purple. 



Select ‘Finish Sketch’. 



IMPORTANT NOTE: Everywhere you see a purple line is where the laser (or water jet) will cut. If your sketch contains a line that goes through the part (like the picture below) then your part will be cut into 2 pieces! Always double check your sketch to make sure that it only contains lines that you want cut, and that it is not missing any important features. 





Save the sketch as a DXF

Right click your sketch in the browser on the left. 

Rename your sketch to ‘DXF’ so that others know what the sketch is for. 



Right click on ‘DXF’ and select ‘Save as DXF’.



Save the sketch wherever you’d like with a name that makes sense. 



You’re done!

How-To_ Battle Harden.txt:
How to battle harden your motors

	This link leads to a video that gives a detailed video and an example for battle hardening. Battle hardening is the process of putting a glass microbe and epoxy mix between the magnets of motors so that the magnets will not shift and potentially shatter if the motor is hit.

SAFETY: 

Make sure to wear a mask AT ALL TIMES when applying the glass microbe and epoxy mix. If you inhale a lot of the glass microbes you will get microplastics in your lungs and probably die from cancer :( 

Wear gloves AT ALL TIMES when applying the glass microbe and epoxy mix. The stuff can get on your skin and it would be yucky because it would then become hard to peel off.

When applying acetone, make sure that the cup you are putting the acetone in is resistant to acetone and will not get immediately melted. Acetone reacts with plastic and will literally melt through some cups so yeah.

STEP 1:

Take apart each motor: The motors will have c-clips and shaft collars that will need to be taken off in order to pull apart the top and bottom in order to harden each piece. Another thing that will be on the motor is these golden ring things but you can just take those off and store them for later, they are basically just mini bearings for the motor. Be careful not to lose any parts!

Shaft collar:

Screw these off using an appropriate allen key. If the screw is stripped and if you do not need the original shaft, you can use the drill press to take out the excess metal inside of the shaft collar. OR you can use the saw to saw off a large part of the shaft collar because the collar is made out of aluminum which is softer than steel.

C-clips: 

When you take these off, make sure not to break them because it will be nice to have them later.

STEP 2:

The motor separated into top and bottom should look like the picture below:

TOP:



BOTTOM:



Make the mixture: The video explains in a good way on how to measure out the mixture starting at 7:15.

Apply the mixture to the sections detailed in the video at 9:45. Make sure to quickly take off parts of the mixture before it dries so you save yourself some work scraping the rest off later on. The video goes into good detail so just watch that instead.

STEP 3:

After the mixture has all been applied, all that is left is scraping the rest of the mixture off. Some useful methods are:

USE A BOXCUTTER to rub off excess material from the bottoms. This should be pretty easy, as all you have to do is find where the material is sticking out on the bottoms and cut it off.

APPLY ACETONE to the insides of the tops, especially because it is hard to get into the tops, especially with metal objects. A method that worked with us was to tape paper towels to the tips of popsicle sticks, and then dip it into the acetone and rub it on the magnets inside of the tops, but also make sure that you don’t get acetone in-between the magnets.

SCRAPE WITH A FLATHEAD SCREWDRIVER the insides of the tops; this will take off lots of excess material easily, especially after acetone has been applied and all of the material is loosened. However, you might encounter a problem with the excess little bits and material that are in the tops.

USING DOUBLE SIDED TAPE TO TAKE THE BITS OFF works really well. You can get masking tape and shove it into the tops and rub it around which will catch all of the bits and take it off.

SPINNING THE MOTOR. You can try to put together the tops and bottoms and spin the motor over and over again which will also gradually take off excess material. This will make bits of material that you can also take off using double sided tape.

STEP 4:

Repeat and suffer

STEP 5: 

When the motors are fully battle hardened, compare them to a control group of motors. The battle hardened motors can be a little bit rougher than normal, but they should be relatively smooth as well. 

They should look a little something like this:



Reference the video as well to see how a good battle hardened motor should look like.

You are done! Time for therapy. Here is a useful website for free therapy options offered by Cornell Health.
How-To_ Program ESCs.txt:
How to program AM32 ESCs 

This guide was written as a response to repeat robotics sending ESCs that were incorrectly configured. I (Jason) am unsure whether this guide is specific to the model of ESC we worked on. I think it should apply to all AM32 ESCs regardless. 

Reflashing the Firmware

Required Materials: 

1 ESC with soldered power wires

1 usb linker (USE THIS SPECIFIC ONE FOUND IN TEAM SUPPLIES, we’ve had trouble with other USB linkers not working) 



1 lipo battery

1 usb c cable

1 windows computer



Unfortunately, this method only works with windows laptops due to the software required. 



Method: 

Download all the files from this drive folder. 

Unzip the file named “config tool.” 

Navigate to the .exe file named “SerialPortConnector.”

Run the program.  

If you get a pop up like the following stating that the program might be dangerous, press the “more info” button and select “Run anyway.” 



The program should look like the following. 



Select the “Serial Port” dropdown and take note which COM Ports are present. There may be none depending on the computer used. 

Plug the USB linker into the PC using the usb c cable. 

Plug signal wires from the ESC into the usb linker. Make sure the black wire from the ESC corresponds to the ground pin on the usb linker. 



Provide power to the ESC by connecting it to the lipo battery. At this stage, the ESC should be connected to the PC via the USB linker and the battery. 

In the settings tab on the ESC config tool, select the “Serial Port” dropdown and navigate to the COM port that is newly detected, compared to step 7. Check the “Direct Connect” box, and then press “Connect” to the right. 

From the newly shown options, click “M1”



ESC settings should populate (they won’t look the same as this)



Select the “Load Config File” button on the right hand side. 



Navigate to RepeatDrive_AM32.ecf and choose “Open.” 

Press “Save Settings” towards the bottom of the window. The top status window should change to “WRITE EEPROM SUCCESSFUL”



Press M1 again to verify that the ESC settings are saved. It should show the below screen once again. 



Press “Close Connection” and unplug everything. 


How to program ESCs using BlHeliSuite32

The Arduino Method



VIDEOS AND DOCUMENTS REFERENCED:

Flashing an ESC using an Arduino

Programming ESC using Software

Determining your ESC settings 



This method requires the following materials: 

1 Arduino

1 Arduino to USB cable 

1 ESC compatible with BlHeliSuite32 

2 Wires/Jumper cables 

1 Laptop with a USB port

1 Battery or power supply



Step 1: Flashing the ESC

Download the required software from the following link (options for Windows/Mac/Linux are available):

https://github.com/bitdump/BLHeli/releases 

Unzip the folder and run BLHeliSuite32

Click on the Make Interfaces tab 

Select the appropriate option from the Arduino Board dropdown

For this we are using Uno w/ ATmega328

Do not change the Baud option, the default option should suffice

Click the Arduino BlHeli Bootloader option

Using jumper cables, connect the black female wire of the ESC to the GND pin of the Arduino

Depending on the Arduino board, connect the white female wire of the ESC to a numbered digital pin on the Arduino

Arduino Uno: digital pin 11

Arduino Nano: digital pin 2

Arduino Mega: digital pin 51

Connect Arduino to computer via USB connector

For the Port option, click on the option that displays, should be something like “COM4USB2.0”, may not be exactly the same

If nothing shows up, may need to download Arduino software on your computer in order to install the necessary port drivers:

https://support.arduino.cc/hc/en-us/articles/360019833020-Download-and-install-Arduino-IDE (Windows/Mac/Linux download)

Click the Arduino BlHeli Bootloader button, then press Yes for the following popup



Step 2: Programming the ESC 

Connect the Battery to the ESC

Switch to the ESC Setup Tab

On the Select BLHeli_32 Interface tap, click on BLHeli_32 Bootloader (USB/COM)

Ensure the appropriate option for Port is selected

Click on the Connect button

This should connect the ESC to the interface. If it fails to connect and states that “ESC is not connected to power”, use a multimeter to make sure current is flowing through the ESC and that all circuit components are soldered correctly. 

Customize the ESC settings to fit your robot’s needs. Further detail on what each ESC setting means can be found here. 

Once you are satisfied with your settings, click the Write Setup button. This will save all the settings onto the ESC.  

If you want to see the settings currently on the ESC, click the Read Setup button.

In the top-left corner, click the ESC Setup button, and then click Save setup to ini file. This will save your ESC settings as a file on your computer that you can upload to other ESCs.

To add ESC settings from an ini file to a new ESC, go to the top-left corner, click the ESC Setup button, and then click Read setup from ini file. 



After writing the setup, you are now done with programming your ESC!








How to program ESCs using VGood Programming Card 

	This is the VGood Programming Card, which allows you to program ESCs with BECs (Battery Elimination Circuits). To program ESCs using this card, plug your powered ESC into the PROGRAM plug on the top. The buttons will flash, which means the VGood card is connected to the ESC. Then. select the setting you want on the lit up row, and continue down the card until every setting is programmed. 



For more information on each setting and its meaning, please refer to this YouTube video.
How-To_ CAD in Fusion (Guidelines & Tips:
How to CAD in Fusion: Guidelines and Tips



This guide will go over some tips and tricks to make sure that your CAD sketch, part, or assembly is super duper organized and easily accessible by other people. 



Anna Boese’s Number 1 CAD Tip: The shortcut ‘s’ will bring up a search bar where you can search any feature within Fusion (for example, Extrude, Mirror, Joint, etc). Use this before asking someone where to find something in Fusion! 



Sketches



Why are my lines turning different colors and what do those colors mean? 



Blue: A blue line in your sketch means that the line (or shape) is unconstrained. This is what you will see when you first draw something in a sketch. 

Unconstrained or undefined means that that particular element in your sketch is free to move unpredictably. This is bad! You want all of your sketches to be fully defined so that they are not floating in space and so other people can understand why your sketch is shaped the way it is. 



Blue lines in Fusion. Note that there are two black lines, and those are defined by being coincident with the origin and being horizontal and vertical. 



Black: A black line means that your sketch is defined or constrained using either the dimension tool or using other constraint methods, such as ‘coincident,’ ‘horizontal,’ or ‘collinear’ (as seen in the first picture below). This is good! You want all of your sketches to be fully constrained. 

Side note: If you apply a dimension and you get the error seen in the second picture (the one that says ‘over-constrained sketch’), that means that you’re trying to apply a dimension to a sketch that is already fully defined—aka, the dimension you’re adding is both unnecessary and impossible to apply. A driven dimension is simply a reference dimension that you can look at but cannot edit. 



Constraints listed in the bar at the top of your screen while in sketch mode. 



An example of a pop-up you’ll get when you try to overconstrain a sketch. 



Purple: A purple line is a projected sketch. If you press ‘p’ on your keyboard while in sketch mode and select a face or a different sketch, then you can project an element onto your sketch plane. If the reference face or sketch updates, then your sketch should (typically) update with it. Be careful using projected sketches! If you then delete the reference face or sketch, then Fusion no longer knows where the projection came from, and you’ll get a bunch of yellow lines, which is bad!



Projecting the face of a cube onto your sketch plane. 





The resulting sketch in purple. 



Yellow: A yellow line means that Fusion knows there is supposed to be a sketch element there, but it doesn’t know where it came from. This is typically a result of misusing a projected sketch. If you have any yellow elements in a sketch, you must redefine them! Yellow sketches are bad. 



This sketch is yellow because I deleted the cube that the projected face was referenced from. 



Green: A green sketch indicates that the sketch is fixed. Generally, this is bad because other users will not understand how your sketch is defined. There are two ways that your sketch can be green: 

You manually fixed the sketch: This happens when you right-click an element of the sketch and hit ‘Fix/UnFix’. Once it is fixed, it will not move. 

You redefine the sketch plane of a projected sketch: If your sketch contains a projection and then you redefine your sketch plane, the new sketch will turn your projection into a fixed sketch. If you do this, you should delete the sketch and re-project it so it turns purple. 



What are parameters and why should I use them? 



Under Modify → Parameters, you can add User Parameters, which are variables that you can use when defining your sketches. 





An example of a user parameter. 



When you make a sketch, you can then use this parameter as though entering a variable into an equation. 





An example usage of a parameter. 



A dimension with an fx next to it means that it has been defined using a parameter. 





What a parameterized dimension looks like. 



So why should I use parameters? 

Parameters help people understand what your dimension means. Using the pulleyDiameter parameter will make more sense to someone looking at your sketch than just the number 2. 

Parameters will make adjustments to your part file easy in the long run. If you have a parameter wheelDiameter that you use when defining your chassis, if the wheel diameter changes, you can easily change it in your parameters and you won’t have to individually change 200 different dimensions in a bunch of different sketches. 

Other tips on using parameters: 

You don’t need a parameter for every single dimension. Be sure to use your parameters in an effective way that is easy to understand by someone looking at your part file. If it’s a one-time dimension, like a fillet, a parameter probably isn’t necessary. (But if you have a bunch of fillets that you want to be the same size, then it might be useful…)

Give your parameters names that other people will understand! Diameter is not a useful name. weaponPulleyDiameter is a useful name. 





My sketch is yellow in the timeline—what does this mean? 





An example of a yellow sketch in a timeline.	



This could mean 2 things:

You have a projected sketch but Fusion can no longer figure out where the sketch is projected from (see the explanation on yellow lines above). 

You have to redefine your sketch plane, which is necessary if you drew your sketch on a surface that no longer exists. 

Right click the sketch in the timeline. 

Hit ‘Redefine Sketch Plane.’ 

Click a new plane on which your sketch should reside. 

This could be an XY plane, YZ plane, XZ plane, a face of a body, or a construction plane that you made yourself. 

The yellow should be gone now!





Organizing a part file



Using the timeline



The timeline is the thing at the bottom of your screen: 





It keeps track of the “operations” that occur in your part file, and the order in which it happens. 

The gray bar that you see at the end of the timeline can be moved so you can essentially reverse time. This is useful if you realize that you need to do an operation before another operation (for example, adding a construction plane to use for the mirror operator). 



Organizing your timeline into groups

You can organize your timeline into groups: 

Select a bunch of operations with ctrl → right click → hit ‘Create Group’

You can then rename this group into something useful. 

Some examples of useful groups: 

Fillet groups

Joint groups

Hole groups

Caveat: Unfortunately, there is no way to add a new operation to an existing group. The only way to do this is to delete your previous group and make a new group with the new feature. 



Capture design history

When you upload a part into Fusion (from McMaster, maybe), it will not have a timeline. To ensure that you have a timeline before making changes to the parts: 

Right click the part name in the browser. 



Select 'Capture Design History’ at the bottom. 

Now you can begin editing! (If you want to.)





Labeling your sketches

DO IT! 

Labeling your sketches is essential for organization. It is helpful for you to remember when, where, and how you’ve defined your part, and it’s helpful to others who are trying to understand you CADding process. 

To label your sketch: 

Right click your sketch in the browser. 

Hit ‘Rename’. 







Organizing an assembly

What is a component? 

A component is a fancy word for a part. It can come from a variety of places: 

You can insert a component from a part you made by right-clicking the part in the Data Panel (the place where the files are) and clicking ‘Insert into Current Design’. 

It is not recommended that you edit the part in this assembly file! This is called editing in place, and it makes it extremely difficult for other people to understand how you constructed your part. You should only edit parts in your part files. 

You can import a part from McMaster by downloading the file from the website, uploading it to Fusion, and inserting it into your design as described in the previous point. 

(It is possible to directly import a McMaster part from Fusion, but this is not recommended since it creates a base feature and you are unable to rename the part or easily use it in other files.)

You can create a component by selecting Create → New Component. 

A good example of using this feature is in the ‘Chassis Assembly’ in Benjamin Rimshot Johm, Esq.

This allows you to create your parts in the same file without having separate part files that are then inserted into the assembly. 

To edit this component, make sure that it is activated in the browser by clicking the dot next to the component (see the picture below). 





An activated component in an assembly. 



How many assemblies, subassemblies, subsubassemblies, etc. should I have? 



A part file contains only the part and no components. 

This is where editing should take place. 





A part file contains no components in the browser. 



An assembly file should generally only contain components. 

You should generally not make any edits to parts in an assembly file. 

(There are some exceptions to this rule. See ‘Chassis Assembly’ in Benjamin Rimshot Johm, Esq. for an example.) 

You should label your assembly as ‘Assembly’ in the file name so other people know that it’s an assembly (Fusion does not differentiate automatically between part files and assembly files.) 

Use sub-assemblies with care; do not make unnecessary sub-assembles. Having 1 sub-assembly per subsystem is typical. 





An assembly file contains only components in the browser. 





Here’s an example of part organization for a kinetic robot: 

Full assembly (contains components only)

Chassis assembly (contains components only, with exceptions)

Billet

Uprights

Top plate

Chassis screws

Etc. 

Drivetain assembly

Wheel

Motor

Gearbox

Pulley

Spacers

Drivetrain screws

Etc. 

Weapon assembly

Weapon blade

Weapon shaft

Bearings

Spacers

Pulleys

Etc. 

Battery

ESCs

Weapon motor (if not a hub motor)

Inter-subsystem screws

Configurations



What is a joint and how do I use one properly? 



A joint positions components relative to each other in an assembly.

To joint components:

Make sure they are components not bodies!

Click the joint button in Assemble (or press “J”)







Select the place you want to join on the first component





Select the place you want to join on the second component







Click “OK” (or press “Enter”)





Make sure to name the joint!

Click the folder “Joints”

Double click the joint and name it according to naming convention

[Name of component 1] to [name of component 2]

How-To_ Preload (for Spinning Weapon Ass:
How to preload (for spinning weapons)



Proper preloading is an essential step when designing and assembling spinning weapons: with the right preload, a weapon stack can spin freely while remaining very strong against impacts. When the preload is too tight, the weapon doesn’t spin freely, and when the preload is too loose, the bearings can shake themselves apart.



This preloading guide applies only to spinning weapons that rotate around stationary (“dead”) shafts, which are typically steel bolts. If you’re designing or working with a different kind of spinning weapon, preloading may still be important, but you’ll need to do more research to make sure you’re applying it in the right way. Additionally, preloading is not essential for all bearing types, but for angular-contact bearings (ACBs), it is essential. This guide focuses on preloading with ACBs, using Rosie’s weapon assembly as an example (labeled in the figure below).





But what is preloading anyway?

A bearing is preloaded when there is a constant axial load applied to it by the assembly, as shown below. F1 is applied to the outer race, and F2 is applied to the inner race, forcing those races towards each other to keep the balls from being able to rattle. For ACBs like this, it’s possible for the bearing to rattle itself apart at high speeds if there is no preload. 



However, too much preload can cause the bearing to seize up. If F1 and F2 are too large, the balls and the races will be squeezed tightly, forcing them to deform as they rotate. This causes unnecessary wear, and at high speeds, it can create enough heat to melt the plastic holder that keeps the balls in place. So we want to get F1 and F2 (the preload force) just right.

How do we get the preload force just right?

Short answer: by sandwiching them with perfectly sized spacers. To see what this means, let’s look at a cross section of the complete weapon assembly. The bolt’s head and the nut squeeze the assembly, and the small purple arrows show the force propagating toward the central area between the two ACBs.







Analyzing this from the left end to the center:

The bolt head (red) pushes inward on the chassis plate (red outline).

The chassis plate pushes on a spacer (yellow).

The spacer pushes on the inner race of the LEFT ACB (orange).

The ACB pushes on two things:

The preload spacer (red)

The force travels directly through the inner race.

The weapon blade/pulley assembly (cyan/green)

The force travels from the ACB’s inner race through the balls and outer race before actually pushing on the weapon blade.

Analyzing this from the right end to the center:

The nut (blue) pushes on the chassis plate (red outline).

The chassis plate pushes on a spacer (yellow).

The spacer pushes on the inner race of the RIGHT ACB (orange).

The ACB pushes on two things:

The preload spacer (red)

The force travels directly through the inner race.

The weapon blade/pulley assembly (cyan/green)

The force travels from the ACB’s inner race through the balls and outer race before actually pushing on the weapon pulley.



From these analyses, we can see there are two things being compressed in the center:

The central spacer, between the inner races (length A)

The weapon blade/pulley, between the outer races (length B)

If A is shorter than B, then when the nut is tightened, the force will travel through the balls and outer race of the bearing (this is a preload). If A is longer than B, then when the nut is tightened, the force will only go through the preload spacer (the balls will be loose; there is no preload).



This leaves us with two ways to adjust the preload on a weapon assembly:

By tightening or loosening the nut: this changes the total compressive load through the system, and it’s very easy to adjust without disassembling anything. However, loosening the nut too much can weaken the system overall, and no human can tighten it beyond a certain point.

By changing the length of the preload spacer: since the metal parts compress slightly, it’s possible to distribute the load between the preload spacer and the balls of the ACBs. By tweaking the length, we can put 80% of the load through the preload spacer and 20% of the load through the balls. This lets us tighten the nut more, keeping the assembly strong without applying too much preload to the ACBs.

How do you change the length of the preload spacer without re-manufacturing it? By adding or removing shims. Shims are like extremely thin washers with precise thicknesses, and you can add them between the preload spacer and the inner race of an ACB. This is often tricky and fiddly to do, because the spacer is (and must be) in the center of the weapon assembly.

Super fun exercise that will haunt you until you figure it out

Now that you understand the principles of preloading, try analyzing the forces in Beater B. Barker’s weapon/flywheel assembly. This one has two pairs of ACBs, so it’s twice as fun!



Take a screenshot of the cross section below and draw out the little force arrows. Can you find the preload spacer here? Where would you add shims?
How-To_ Choose ESCs.txt:
How to choose ESCs



Prerequisites

You will need 1 ESC per motor. In order to choose your ESC, you need to know which motors you are using. 



Choosing an ESC

Your motor should have a maximum continuous current rating. Find it. (For example, this motor has a max continuous current of 35A.)

Find an ESC (preferably not from eBay) that has an amperage rating that is at least this value. 

For the example above, you would want a 35A ESC or greater. \

Make sure that the S rating is the same as your battery. 

Make sure that it’s compatible with your motor type (brushed or brushless). 

That’s literally it. 



Bidirectionality

If this ESC is for your drivetrain, you must make sure that your ESC is bidirectional. If it is not explicitly stated as bidirectional, it is not recommended that you order it. 

If it’s not bidirectional, you will not be able to drive backwards. 

For your weapon, this might be something to keep in mind, but may not be a requirement. 

For example, most spinning weapons only need to go in 1 direction. Lifters, however, may need to move in both directions in a controlled manner.
How-To_ Take Care of Your LiPo Battery.t:
How to take care of your LiPo battery

Safety guidelines

Do not charge a LiPo cell above 4.2 V. This can cause the battery to set on fire. 

LiPo cells are permanently and irreparably damaged if discharged below about 2.8 V per cell.

Because LiPo batteries can be unstable, it is important to always store them in LiPo bags and watch the battery when charging them. Give it a poke every once and a while to make sure it’s not heating up too much. 

Always discard a LiPo battery that exhibits early signs of damage, such as “puffy” swelling of the wrapping. 

Never use any charger except for a charger specifically designed for LiPo batteries. 

It is best to charge your battery out of the robot and in a charging bag. 

Charging your battery inside the robot is fine for a few charge cycles (for example, in between matches at competition) but over time it may allow the charge state of individual battery cells to drift from optimum. 

If your battery catches on fire, back away and leave it in the LiPo bag if it is already in a bag. Grab the fire extinguisher by CMR’s table or the sand and use it to extinguish the fire. Sand will also work if a fire extinguisher is not available. Do not use water on a LiPo fire!!!

How to charge your LiPo battery

Always make sure that the black wire goes to the black wire, and the red wire goes to the red wire. 

Plug the main connector of your battery into the battery charger (this connector is most likely a yellow XT60). 

Plug in the balance port to the charger. This is the smaller white connector.

There are different connectors depending on how many cells your battery has. Make sure you plug in the correct one (for example, a 6S battery should plug into the 6S port). 

The balance port makes sure that all of the cells in your battery charge equally, which will prolong the life of your battery. 

The amperage setting on your charger should be the following: 

If your battery is 4200 mAh, you should charge at 4.2 A. If your battery is 2400 mAh, you should charge at 2.4 A, etc. 

The voltage setting on your charger should be the following:

Your battery might have the voltage written directly on it. If there is no voltage, you can calculate the voltage using the following: Voltage = 3.8 * number of cells

For example, for a 2S battery, your voltage setting should be 7.6V (or 3.8*2)

Hold down the charge button.

Confirm your settings. 

Your battery should now be charging!



What Constitutes a Damaged Battery?

Any battery that has excessive swelling, or loses it’s distinct rectangular shape.

At competition, if something indents a battery or damages it in any way beyond the most superficial impacts, you should refrain from using or charging the battery at all costs! If charged or used further, this can cause a fire. AT NRHL, A FIRE IN THE PITS WILL DISQUALIFY THE BOT IMMEDIATELY! DON'T TAKE THE RISK! A fire in the cage will lead to the entire robot getting thrown in the trash, and they will not give you access to it for a long time to make sure it will not explode or set on fire again. DON’T TAKE THE RISK!!!

How to Dispose of a Damaged LiPO/LiHV Battery

In a plastic container, dissolve ½ cup of salt in 1 gallon of cold water. 

Drop the battery into the salt water and leave it there for at least 2 weeks. 

Remove the battery, wrap it in paper, and throw it in the trash.

Restoring Over-Discharged LiPos:

Step 1: Initial Restoration Phase (LiPo < 3.3V/cell)

	Warning: While LiPos are <3.3V/cell, do NOT leave unattended. Constantly monitor through touching batteries to ensure they do not get hot and making sure the battery is not puffing. Always charge batteries in a LiPo bag. NiMh chargers do not detect end-of-charge, so if left unattended LiPo battery will catch fire. 



Use NiMh BATT charger setting (without the balance board connected) with 0.1A until the battery reaches 3.3V * #cells in charge. 

For 6S battery- 19.8V

For 4S battery- 13.2V



Fig 1: Step 1, Initial Restoration Phase.



Fig 2: Photo of charger settings, Step 1.



Step 2: Post-Restoration Phase (LiPo > 3.3V/cell)

Warning: Charge within LiPo battery bag. Always watch the battery while charging. Do not charge to 100% charge, in order to avoid battery damage. 

Charge anywhere between 0.5C and 1C on LIPO BATT mode. The lower the capacitance, the slower the batter will charge, but the safer it will be. Do not exceed 1C.

Example: 1300 mAh 4S (14.8V) battery

1C- Charge at 1.3A

0.5C- Charge at 0.65A

Continue watching the batter as it charges, unplugging as it approaches max 





LiHV Batteries:

LiHV batteries are essentially LiPO batteries, but with a slightly higher voltage, hence the HV meaning High Voltage. For most cases, they can be treated the same as LiPO batteries, however, their maximum voltage is 4.35 Volts per cell, as opposed to 4.2.

You can adjust this by pressing the cycle button when LiPO is flashing on the charger screen, and selecting LiHV instead.

LiHV batteries can still be charged at 4.2 Volts per cell, they will just hold less power than they could.

NOTE: SMC Racing will make custom batteries if you email orders@smc-racing.com

This includes LiHV and LiPO batteries, how custom is custom is yet to be determined (we should email and talk)
How-to_ Bend Titanium Wedges.txt:
How to bend titanium wedges

Notes about titanium bending

In order to achieve a certain bend angle, you have to overshoot your goal angle by about 15°. From there, the titanium will bend backward to the spot that you want it to be in. 

Titanium will break if you try to bend it to about 45°. Be sure to follow the procedure below carefully. 

The procedure outlined in Step 4 below will increase the bend radius, therefore making the plate less susceptible to breaking. (Bigger radius = less stress concentration—remember statics?)

Procedure

All sheet metal bending is done using the sheet metal bender in the Emerson machine shop, which is to your left when you enter the shop.

Clamp your titanium plate onto the machine. 

For bends smaller than 45°:

Bend to whatever angle you want + about 15 extra degrees. 

Done!

For bends at or greater than 45°:

Bend titanium to no more than 55°.

Unclamp and pull the titanium out a few millimeters. 

Re-clampe the plate and bend again.

Repeat until the desired angle is achieved. 

Done!
How-To_ Machine (Guidelines & Tips).txt:
How to machine

The basics

	This link leads to videos that explains how to use the basic functions of the manual mill and manual lathe, along with other machinery like the belt sander and the horizontal bandsaw. Instead of me explaining how to machine, watch these videos; if you’re looking for information about a specific operation (i.e. tapping), open the video and refer to the timestamps in the first few seconds of the video. If a commonly used operation is not explained in these videos, it will be explained in this section. 

The Cornell Official Emerson Machining Manual also has a lot of information that may be useful. 

How to zero the z-axis on the manual mill

NOTE that every single time you change your tool, you have to re-zero your z-axis! So adjust your order of operations accordingly…

Find the shim paper hiding around the shop somewhere—it looks like the picture below. (It looks like tissue paper, but it’s shiny.) Alternatively, if you can’t find shim paper, you can use your part drawing. 

	

Using the rough z-axis adjuster that is at eye-level, position your part so it is sort-of close to your tool. The precise z-axis is a pain to move, so you’ll be happier the less you’ll have to move it. 

LOCK THE ROUGH Z-AXIS by turning the little knob that’s near the big handle (see the figure below). You do not want this to move from here on out, otherwise you’ll lose your zero!



Put your shim paper/part drawing between your part and the tool. Slowly move the precise z-axis (henceforth just known as the z-axis) upward while wiggling your paper simultaneously. The moment the paper gets snagged by the tool and stops moving, don’t move the z-axis anymore!

Zero the z-axis by loosening the grippy part of the handle and rotating the marker part of the handle until the number ‘0’ lines up with the small line. Then, re-tighten the grippy part. (By grippy part, I mean the round part that feels like it has a lot of grip.)

		

If you need your depth to be extra precise, offset your z-axis by the thickness of your paper. You can measure this thickness using calipers. (The shim paper is 0.001” thick.)

You have now zeroed your z-axis! Congrats! Remember that each line on your z-axis handle is 0.001” and there are 100 marks per rotation—therefore, 1 full rotation of the z-axis handle is 0.1”.

If your depth is 0.5”, rotate the handle 5 times.

Etc etc etc…



How to drill off-center holes in a circle

	For example:



	Since the lathe only drills center holes, you’ll need to use the mill. Follow the steps below:

Find a v-block that fits around your part such that the circle is clamped between the v-block and the vise, as shown in the picture below. The part should be resting on parallels, as always. Make sure your part is sticking above the v-block and the vise so you have material you can zero off of. 

		INSERT A PICTURE HERE

Set up the wiggler tool for zeroing. 

For the following step, do not adjust the y-axis!

Touch the wiggler to one side of the circle as you would normally. Zero this side. 

Move the wiggler to the other side without touching the y-axis and touch the wiggler to the other side. DO NOT ZERO. Instead, hit the center-line button (which looks like the picture below) and then hit ‘X.’



The x-axis is now zeroed on the center of your part. Repeat step 3 for the y-axis by using the wiggler tool on the top and bottom of the part without moving the x-axis!

The mill is now zeroed in the center of your part. From here, you can drill all your holes. Hopefully the hole placements in your part drawing are defined using ordinate dimensions from the center! 😀



How to machine plastic

	DON’T 

Common issues

My tap broke!

Oopsie! That sucks. Unfortunately, this probably means that your part is no longer usable (though this may vary on a case-by-case basis). Since the tap is made of a much harder metal than your drill bits, there’s no way to drill through it. You may now take this part home and put it on your wall of failures. 

There are 4 common culprits that lead to tap breaking:

You used too much pressure: When you tap a hole, you should not be pushing downward at all. If you have to use force to get your tap to cut threads, then something is wrong. The only force you should apply is horizontal to twist the tap in a circle. 

You used too much torque: Try not to use a tap handle that is way too big for the hole you’re tapping. There’s no real metric for this, just try to find a tap handle that feels right. If you use one that’s way too big, there’s a bigger chance that small errors can cause your tap to break (like not being completely aligned or hitting the bottom of the hole). 

You continued tapping even when you reached the bottom of the hole: This aligns with #1. Do not use force to go down! When you reach the bottom of the hole or feel any resistance, stop. If you use a “bottoming tap” (which looks like the first picture) as opposed to a “taper tap” (which looks like the second picture) then when you hit the bottom of the hole, your tap will stop instantly.

			



Your tap wasn’t straight: This usually happens if you’re tapping by hand (which is a bit risky, and I don’t recommend it). If you absolutely must tap by hand, always have someone else watching you from multiple angles to make sure you’re tapping straight. 



My parallels keep moving and I can’t get them to stay still!

		This could be for a bunch of reasons. I’ll list a few below:

Your part isn’t square! If it’s not sitting flat against the parallels, it’ll look like the picture below. If possible, try to choose an orientation that consists of the 3 most square sides of your stock so it fits nicely, like the second picture. If there are no 3 sides that are square enough, you’ll have to face one side of your stock, rotate, face another side, rotate again, face a 3rd side, and repeat this process until your part is square enough to secure those parallels. 

	



You didn’t mess with it enough! Sometimes it just takes some wiggling. Something I like to do (which usually works) is press my hand down on the part while I tighten the vise, which helps to secure it a bit better before I use the mallet and then tighten again. 

You didn’t whack it with the hammer hard enough! Give it a really good smack. Don’t be shy, you know you want to. Make sure to smack it when it’s secure in the vise—if you hit it and it’s not secure, it’ll just go flying (or make a really loud noise). 



I turned on the machine and it made a really loud and scary noise!

	This is probably because your machine—whether you’re using a lathe or a mill—wasn’t

 in gear. It’s similar to a bike—if you change gears but the chain slips or gets stuck, no more bike riding for you. 

	On the mill, there is a small lever that you move if you want to shift from high range to low range. If you don't move the lever all the way to one side, your mill will make a terrible noise. Make sure the lever is all the way to one side—if it’s stuck, spin the collet holder in circles until it moves. Spinning the collet holder will shift the gears inside the mill until they align. If you’re spinning and the gear still isn’t locking it into place, try putting it back into the other gear, running it for a few seconds, turning it off, and then trying again. 



On the lathe, it’s a similar issue—you’re probably stuck in-between RPM ranges. Make sure the lever is completely on a single RPM range—if it’s stuck, put the lathe in neutral (by shifting the “on” lever to its middle position) and spin the lathe chuck until the lever clicks into place. 

Feeds, Speeds, and Step Sizes

	This video explains how to calculate RPM based on your tool, part size, and material. The details of this video are summarized below. 







	SFM values can be found in the table below. 

For a mill, the “Diameter” is the size of the cutter (drill bit). On the lathe, “Diameter” refers to the size of the stock if you’re cutting the outside; if you’re boring or drilling a hole, “Diameter” will be the size of the hole. 

	The constant 3.82 is 12/π; it converts surface feet into surface inches. For manual machines, you can replace the 3.82 with the number 4 to make calculations easier. Manual machines will most likely not have the exact RPM value you need, but this formula will give you a good range. Based on what the machine provides, always choose a number under your calculated RPM. 



	The SFM table below is based on high-speed steel (HSS) tools. For carbide tools, you can double these numbers. If you’re not sure what type of tool you have, assume it is an HSS tool. 



SFM Values for Various Materials



Mild steel (i.e. any steel that has not been hardened)

90

Tool steel

50

Mystery steel (i.e. steel stock that you found, but you’re unsure of the alloy or treatment)

50

Hardened steel

50

Aluminum

150

Brass

150

Bronze

100

Stainless steel

40



The following quick guide is for use with the manual machines in Emerson. For any other operation requiring any other tool, refer to the calculations above.

How-To_ Choose a Battery.txt:
How to choose a battery

Reference the Technical Glossary for more info on S-ratings, C-ratings, etc. 



Why LiPo batteries?

High energy density (more energy per cell compared to, say, NiCd batteries). 

Weight efficient. 



How to pick a battery for your robot

Governing equation

Current [A] * Time [h] = Capacity [Ah]

Current: Total current that the battery needs to supply. 

Time: The amount of time that the battery will need to supply the current. (For NHRL matches, this is a maximum of 3 minutes.) 

*Don’t forget to convert to mAh*



Methods for picking your battery

*Choosing a battery is the last electronic piece that should be chosen (except for the wires, which are really the last thing)*



Method 1: Use the equation above. Sum the maximum continuous current for each motor to determine the “motor current.”

Good because: You can determine which battery you want before you test it, and you’ll have a large factor of safety. 

Bad because: This will result in a far higher capacity than you realistically need, since the maximum current is rarely met, typically only for brief moments while spinning up, or when it is stalling due to high torque loads on the weapon (for instance, if you try to spin up against a wall). 

Method 2: Manually test and measure current draw. 

Good because: It will give you a more accurate estimate that takes into account friction and air resistance. 

Bad because: You need to have the entire robot assembled to test this, and you need a method to measure the current in your bot. 

Method 3: Find a robot similar to yours and use their battery. This reference sheet may be helpful. 

Good because: Other builders have already tried and tested it, so you don’t have to. And there is some amount of proof that it will work. 

Bad because: It’s a little iffy. You have to be okay with some hand-wavy reasoning. 

Method 4: For the weapon motor current, use this spreadsheet. 

Good because: It will give you a better estimate of current draw for your weapon motor. 

Bad because: You need to find the drag coefficient somehow…
How-To_ Torch Braze Aluminum_.txt:
How to torch braze aluminum

Helpful Video

This video will explain everything you need to know, but if you’re too lazy to watch it, you can read the directions below. 

Materials

You can get all of these materials at Home Depot or Amazon:

Propane Torch 

Torch Trigger

Aluminum brazing and welding rods

Aluminum Tubing

Steps

*Note: When brazing, the filler rod will always flow towards the heat. Had you clamped your setup vertically and gotten the joint a fair bit hotter, you could have drawn the molten filler towards the torch. could make for a significantly stronger joint.



*Note: For better results, work on a ceramic topped table with a ceramic tile behind the metal you're working on. Try to place ceramic on the sides also. This will reflect a good portion of heat which will otherwise dissipate very quickly.



Chamfer the ends of the aluminum where you are going to bond it (to allow a channel for the braising material)

Clean the aluminum with a brush

Clamp up the tubing

Start heating the intended area with the propane torch (get it to around 700 degrees)

This may take 4-5 minutes

We want it hot enough to melt the brazing rod but not the aluminum

When you think you’ve reached that point start moving the rod down the chamfered channel and when it starts to melt you are hot enough 

Rub the brazing rod until its filled in then finish off with some heat

Repeat process on all sides of the aluminum joint

Additional resources

Working with braze aluminum



Wiki-How
How-To_ Design an Asymmetric Spinning We:
How to design an asymmetric spinning weapon



An asymmetric weapon can achieve twice the bite depth as a symmetric weapon at the same RPM. This is helpful for being extra destructive in the box. But it can be tricky to design one, because you have to make sure it spins about its center of mass (CM). In a symmetric weapon, you can just put the bearing hole in the visual center of the part, but you can’t do that when you go asymmetric. This guide explains how to design an asymmetric weapon, including a nice way to get Fusion to automatically position the hole.

Prerequisites

If you have a basic understanding of parameters and are good at making fully constrained sketches in Fusion, this should be relatively straightforward.

Overview

This guide shows you how to do the following:

Set up a new Fusion file with a point that is positioned based on specifically defined user parameters. This will be the point you reference in any features that need to follow the CM.

Install a script that updates the CM parameters to match the coordinates of the actual center of mass.

Sketch a rough version of the weapon profile, keeping it simple and anchored to the origin, and include a bearing hole anchored to the CM point. Extrude the profile to create a body with a center of mass.

Run the script and verify/debug the model as you adjust your design.

Step 1: Set up the Fusion file

In order for later steps to work properly, you need to create a new Fusion design file with nothing else in it. First, create five user parameters with these exact names and units:

CM_x (units: cm)

CM_y (units: cm)

CM_z (units: cm)

CM_inaccuracy (units: cm)

CM_iterations (no units)

The script won’t work properly unless all five parameters exist and are exactly as shown above. You’ll have to provide a value for each one as you create it, but these initial values don’t matter to the script, so do something like this to keep it from overlapping with the origin point:

CM_x = 1

CM_y = 2

CM_z = 3

CM_inaccuracy = 0

CM_iterations = 0

Now that you have the parameters, create a point that follows them (the CM point). Make three Offset Planes defined using the parameters:











Then define the point as an intersection of those planes:

















Then you can hide the planes and rename your point, like this:



Now you can project this point into any sketches you make.

Step 2: Install the script to make the CM point actually follow the CM

Fusion lets you write custom scripts in Python or C++, which can interact with Fusion in many ways. The script you’ll use looks up the center of mass of the file and writes its XYZ coordinates to CM_x, CM_y, and CM_z (but only if these parameters already exist—you’ll get an error if they don’t). The script is available in a zip file: CenterOfMassParameters.zip.



Install the script by downloading the zip file and moving it to...

on Windows: %AppData%\Autodesk\Autodesk Fusion 360\API\Scripts

on Mac: ~/Library/Application Support/Autodesk/Autodesk Fusion/API/Scripts

Then extract it there. It should end up in its own folder called CenterOfMassParameters.

Step 3: Sketch and extrude the weapon blade

Once you know what general shape you want out of the weapon, you can sketch it on one of the origin planes. To keep the profile stable when the script updates the center of mass, you should constrain at least one major feature at the origin. Otherwise, feel free to constrain features to the CM point and each other—just keep things simple so you can fix it if something goes wrong during a center-of-mass update.



Having sketched the profile, extrude it to create a body that has a center of mass. The script won’t work unless there’s a body in the file.



Note: you can add other parts to the file if, for example, you want the weapon shape to account for the weight of an off-center screw. Just make sure every part (including the weapon blade itself) is the right material/density/weight.

Step 4: Run the script and verify the results

Once you have the script installed, you can access it through the menu shown in the picture below, or by pressing Shift+S and running CenterOfMassParameters. Fusion should find the script automatically when you open the Scripts and Add-Ins dialogue, but if CenterOfMassParameters doesn’t show up, try restarting Fusion.





Since you’ve set up the document well in step 1, you should be able to just run the script by clicking on it and clicking Run. This will update CM_x, CM_y, and CM_z to match the actual center of mass of the part.



This script iterates for you, and here’s why: if you’ve dimensioned any features based on the center-of-mass point you made, those features will move each time the script updates the center of mass. This, in turn, will change the object’s center of mass. To deal with this, the script runs iterations of this process until either:

The CM moves less than 0.01 cm from the last iteration, or

It runs 50 iterations. If this happens, you need to change (most likely simplify) your design to make the iterative process converge.

You can tweak the tolerance and max iteration count by editing the code and saving.

Important: check that the script is working properly!

There’s always a chance something has changed about Fusion’s API, or that something about your file is tripping up the script and giving incorrect results. You can check for this by showing the center of mass point in a way that doesn’t rely on the script.



You can find an option to display the center of mass in the Utilities tab, Inspect menu, as shown below. Unexpectedly, this non-selectable display object will only update when you orbit your view around the part. Make sure to orbit frequently when checking for discrepancies.

How-To_ Design a Chassis.txt:
How to design a chassis



Configurations





Materials
How to program your transmitter

A transmitter is the remote controller that you hold to control the robot. It’s commonly confused with the receiver, a small box that sits inside the robot taking instructions from the transmitter and sending them to the ESCs. Since it’s an important part of transmitter setup, this guide covers how to set up a receiver too. 

What kind of transmitter are you using?

This is an important question, because the process is completely different for different transmitters. On CRC as of Spring 2024, we have two kinds of transmitters:

FRSky Taranis X-Lite S

Red, looks kind of like a gaming controller

More expensive

Has more programmable switches, buttons, and knobs

Fancy: supports many model configs, telemetry, and complicated sensitivity curves

Runs on rechargeable batteries, and can be charged via Micro-USB

Used for Rosie and Beater B. Barker so far

FlySky FS-i6

Black, looks like an RC plane controller

Cheaper

Simpler, but perhaps has a more confusing interface and settings navigation system

Runs on AA batteries (not rechargeable)

Used for all other bots so far

What receiver are you using?

This is an equally important question, because the receiver has to use the same protocol as the transmitter. This means a receiver that works with the FlySky FS-i6 won’t work with the FRSky Taranis X-Lite. Double check what protocols are supported by the transmitter you’re using, and select a receiver that uses one of those protocols.

How to get a receiver to work

Make sure it has power. This is easiest to provide using the BEC output from an ESC.

The BEC output is almost always the middle wire of the 3-pin connector on little wires that comes out of the ESC. If there’s no middle wire, that ESC doesn’t have a BEC.

Make sure you’re connecting the 3-wire connectors in the right orientation. The markings are hard to see, and often the signal and negative markings look quite similar. If an ESC isn’t initializing the way you’re expecting, try flipping the 3-wire connector.

Setup: FrSky Taranis X-Lite

Get the transmitter (it looks like this)

[case, closed]   [transmitter in case, open]



Make sure it’s charged: plug the transmitter into a USB phone charger with a micro-USB cable.

You can’t use the transmitter while doing this. If you need to use the transmitter while also charging the batteries, you can swap to a charged pair of batteries and charge the old ones on the dedicated charger we have. See Appendix A1: Charging the batteries externally  how to swap the batteries and charge them externally: 

Make sure the antenna is on: screw the antenna onto the top

 

Press and hold the power button (button 8) to turn it on

How navigation works

Joystick 1 is the navigation control joystick– to move between menus, long-hold this joystick to either side to switch between menus.

Button 2 is the back button- press this button to exit out of any option that is selected

Button 3 is a select button. Clicking this button allows you to select and change setting. 

Joysticks 4 and 5 are the throttle joysticks. These are used to control the robot, but do not have any use in adjusting the settings. Joystick 4 is for controlling the starboard side of the robot, and Joystick 5 is for controlling the port side of the robot. 

Button 6, The + pad, is mostly just for adjusting trims and not used for adjusting the ++settings.

Switches 7 and 8 are switches that can be configured depending on what you need to toggle. For Beater B Barker, these switches shut off/turn on the weapon and flywheel.  






Program: FrSky Taranis X-Lite



Go to the MIXES screen





Select the channel with the ESC you want to program

As an example, I will use CH3



Select Edit





Select Source

While selected, move the control you want the ESC to be bound to





To reverse the direction of a motor, set Weight to -100





To set a switch (typically used for weapon ESCs), scroll down and repeat step 4 with Switch





To bind multiple controls to one channel, select the channel

Select Insert After

Repeat step 4





Example video:

drive.google.com/file/d/1-B6lAepcTC9rxdcHlyd-PQhjrbcpKTpo/view?usp=drive_link 






Appendix A - Taranis X-Lite

Appendix A1: Charging the batteries externally

The battery covers are circled below– they unscrew in the direction indicated, and each ‘leg’ holds one 18500 battery. These are RECHARGEABLE lithium ion batteries - don’t throw them away, even though they’re shaped like disposable ones!

 [Battery coming out of socket]



Get the 18500 battery charger (a very specific thing — this is the one we have)



Put the battery in it

Plug in the USB cable to a phone charger?

How-To_ Make a Part Drawing.txt:
How to make a part drawing from a CAD model

How to make a part drawing:

Open Fusion. 

In the top left of the screen, there is a box that says “Design.” Click the dropdown menu and select “Drawing,” then “From Design.”





If your part is a component of a greater assembly: In the box that appears, under “Contents,” change “Full Assembly” to “Select.” From there, you can select the part that you want to make a drawing of. (It’s easiest to do this from the dropdown menu to the left as opposed to clicking directly on the CAD. That way you know you’re selecting the correct part). 





























Under “Template,” select “CRC Part Drawing Template” to make sure your part drawing is the correct formatting. 

If “Part Drawing Template” does not appear, go to: Browse → Templates and Backups → Templates → CRC Part Drawing Template

Click OK. 

Double check a few settings:

On the left, hover over “Document Settings” and click the little gear on the right. 

Make sure your units are in inches. 

Change “Linear Precision” to 0.1234 and “Angular Precision” to 0.123. 

From there, start making your drawing! 




For MechE purposes:

This section will outline some tips for how to make efficient and effective part drawing, so that your machinist can go to the machine shop and NOT have to do any math!



Projected views

Always use projected views! (Unless you’re putting an isometric view in the corner for reference.) That way the machinist does not have to guess which side of the part the drawing is referring to. Projected views can be found under Create → Projected View (or the shortcut P). 

Symmetry

If your part has symmetry, use centerlines so you don’t have to do more work than you have to. Centerlines can be found under Geometry → Centerline. Use this to identify the axis across which the part is symmetric. Also make a text note in the empty box that says “Symmetric about centerline(s)” so it’s extra clear to the machinist. 

Ordinate Dimensioning

Under the “Dimensions” tab on the top bar there is an option labeled “Ordinate Dimension.” This is especially useful for parts with lots of dimensions since it vastly clears up the space by creating the dimensions from a common zero point. Use this feature as often as you can to make the drawing as clean as possible. There are pictures below for comparison. 

Ordinate dimensions are also much easier for the machinist to use, since it mimics the way the machine actually works. 





			Bad						Good





Hole Tool

All of the holes in the CAD should be made using the Hole Tool, which means that in the drawing, Fusion can automatically dimension the hole with the correct features. Under the “Text” tab on the top bar there is a “Hole and Thread Note” option. Click on this, then click on the hole you want to dimension. This note should include the number of holes that the note pertains to, so you don’t have to repeat this for every single hole. 

See the “Side tangent about holes and threads” section for more information about what all of the stuff on your hole note means. 

Other things to include

In the box in the bottom right corner, be sure to include other features like tolerances and units. The drawing below has typical values for these features, and is also a good example of ordinate dimensioning (good job Ricky👍). 

Don’t forget the thickness!! That is usually the most missed dimension since you need a separate projected view from it. (The drawing below doesn’t have it because the thickness is included under “Materials,” but it’s good practice to include it in the drawing anyway so the machinist doesn’t have to look for it.)

Example drawing:








Side tangent about holes and threads

Below is a table of common symbols you’ll see related to your Hole and Thread Note. 



Symbol

What it means

What you should do about it (if anything)

[A number]X

i.e. 4X

There are 4 holes on this part that have the same features as this hole.

Nothing



Diameter: A number following this symbol will indicate the diameter of the hole before the tapping operation.

If this hole is going to be tapped, make sure that the number indicated after the diameter is an actual drill size. Drill sizes are either fraction or numbered; look up which drill bit most closely matches your hole size, and then put that size in parenthesis next to the number so your machinist doesn’t have to look anything up while they’re machining!



For example: 





Counterbore: A number following this symbol will indicate the depth of the counterbore.

Nothing



Countersink: This will be accompanied by a diameter and an angle that the countersink should be. 

Nothing



Depth: The number following this symbol indicates how deep the hole should be. 

If you know that the hole is a through hole and does not require a certain depth, then remove this symbol and its number and replace it with the word THRU. It’s more simple and compact, and makes more sense to the machinist. 

[A number] - [Another number]

i.e. 10-24, ¼-20, etc.

This indicates the type of thread: The first number tells you what the diameter is, and the second number tells you the number of threads per inch. 



Note that for diameters below ¼”, the standard turns to number instead of fractions. 

i.e. A #10 screw is smaller than a ¼” screw, and a #8 screw is smaller than #10. 

Nothing

UNC

Unified Coarse Threads: Indicates that the thread type is coarse. (This is what we usually use.)

Nothing

UNF

Unified Fine Threads: Indicates that the thread type is fine.

Nothing

2A or 2B or anything of the sort

Represents the class of thread. 



1A, 2A, and 3A apply to external threads. 



1B, 2B, and 3B apply to internal threads. 

The 1, 2, or 3 class isn’t super necessary for our purposes, so feel free to delete (but it doesn’t matter too much).

LH

Indicates the direction of the thread (right-handed or left-handed). 

You should never see LH! Delete an LH if you see it!



This happens if people mirror their hole features in the CAD.



For Marketing purposes:

This section will outline how to get good line drawings of robots in any view (side view, isometric, etc.) using Fusion. You can use this for merch, advertising, or whatever you’d like!



For example: 





Open Fusion

Open the main file for the bot (the drawing will look exactly like the model you choose)



Click design








Click drawing, then from design







 Just click OK





NOW DO NOT CLICK ANYWHERE! There should be a little pixelated robot following your cursor as you move it on the drawing space, it looks hella jank but just trust the process

Clicking isn’t the end of the world, if you do click scroll down to step 9





Now you can change settings as you need. Decrease the scale ratio to make the drawing bigger (try 1:2), or change the perspective of the drawing in orientation







Once you’re done, click to place the robot down then click OK

The drawing is now done! But there are some other things on it

If you accidentally clicked in step 6: right click on the outline and click move to move the drawing

to resize, right click and click edit view



9a. Once you hit move just click anywhere on the robot then move your mouse and it will move. When you’re done, hit ok



To remove the words, just select it, right click, and hit delete (you can also hit the delete button on the keyboard). Do the same with the outer box.





It should look like this:





Now you have to export it! Click the drop down from export and click export PDF, then save it to your computer (not to fusion)





Now you need a png to remove the background to the outline, so I just take a screenshot of the pdf zoomed in (use F11 for better quality image? Doesn’t rly matter)





Use https://remove-white-background.imageonline.co/ or a related background removing website to remove all the white so it’s just the outline

I like that website because you can scale how much white you remove from the photo





You’re done! 

If you want, you can edit the photo in Procreate, Photoshop, etc., just alpha lock the transparent image and draw over it with black because there is a tiny outline in white… 

Same goes for if you need a white outline

Step 1: Create a Render

          Before:                                                After:

	

 



First, go to Render Tab (under left top corner where it says design)



Generative Design = It does CAD for you

Render = Pretty Pics

Manufacture = CNC Toolpaths

Top Bar Learning:

Scene Settings in all the Detail you’ll add to the “camera” and “scene”

There will be a library of pics on the bottom once you render!

Step 2: Editing the Scene with Scene Settings 



Three settings: Environment, Ground, Camera



Environment:



Brightness = Light on Object

Position = Position of environment and determines reflections and shadows (height + rotation of light)

Background = Color behind object

NOTE: Still use your mouse settings to move the object around!



Ground:



Ground Plane = creates the floor/ground, inserts shadows

Flatten Ground = puts object on the ground rather than in the air

Reflections = adds a reflection of the object like water to the ground



Camera



Perspective view makes the setting look real

Orthographic view is where all the lines in the shot are the same distance from the camera

Focal Length = Determines the feel of the object (small focal length makes the object feel bigger)

^ Can make it like a go pro!

Reminder: zoom in and pan to place the camera anywhere!

Exposure = how long the camera lens is open to collect light (brightness) (phones automatically adjust this)

Depth of Field = this is NOT visible until you start the In-Canvas render (this is the blur from things being too far or too close to the camera, note that the default is a loot of blur)

Aspect Ratio = the shape of the screen width over the height (16:9 is the most common and is what computers are)

Additional Settings
