How-To_ Safely Test Your Robot.txt:
How to safely test your robot in the test box



Safety is the most important thing to keep in mind during testing. Even when you are testing a system that’s already been tested before, problems such as sparking or fires can happen at any time, so always follow safety protocols!



BEFORE TESTING:

Make sure you are aware of the nearest fire extinguisher. For LiPo batteries, you should use a Carbon-Dioxide extinguisher or an ABC Dry Chemical Extinguisher 

Using water on these components will light them on fire more. Please don’t do that.

Prepare the test box. Robots should always be tested in the textbox. Even if the weapon will not be spinning, the testbox can help smother and separate you from the robot in the event of it lighting on fire. 

Removing the weapon lock should be the last thing you do before immediately shutting the test box. The safest order of operations is:

First, turn on the transmitter

Second, turn on the power switch

(Doing this in the opposite order may result in interfering with the fail-safe on the transmitter.) 

Finally, remove the weapon lock and IMMEDIATELY close the test box.

Not following this order can lead to ESCs lighting on fire, injuries from a weapon erroneously spinning, and destruction of electronics.





DURING TESTING: 

Do not open the text box under any circumstances. Opening the textbox can lead to shrapnel or fumes injuring someone. 

If a hole opens up in the textbox, cease testing the robot immediately. Testing must be paused until the hole can be fixed. It is necessary to have a fully enclosed testbox. 





WHAT TO TEST FOR:

According to the Riobotz Combot Tutorial, the most common causes for a robot to lose a match are:

Battery connectors or other wires getting loose 

Solution: Use good quality connectors, always use ring terminals over fork terminals, and use liquid electrical tape or hot glue

Motors, batteries, or other components getting loose

Solution: Avoid using nylon ties or clamps, tighten critical screws before each match, use threadlockers or spring locks

Chains coming off from sprockets

Solution: Make sure sprockets are well aligned, avoid exposed sprockets, or replace chains with timing belts that withstand larger misalignments.

Heavy impacts due to fall damage:

Solution: Test robot by dropping it from 6ft up, which is around the highest one of our robots would be flung into the air.

Improperly charged or low capacity batteries:

Solution: Always use electronic chargers, check battery voltage before each match, and calculate AND test robot’s consumption under real conditions. 

Smoking ESCs:

Solution: Always match the maximum acceptable current in the controller with the motor specs, if a wheel or a spinning weapon gets stuck, turn it off to avoid stalling the motor. 

Rupture of rivets, screws, nuts:

Solution: never use rivets, always use hardened steel screws and nuts (class 8.8 or 10.9 for hex screws, class 12.9 for Allen, and appropriate diameters for what they will be fastening). 

Low-clearance robots getting stuck in the arena:

Solution: Make sure you have a ground clearance of at least ¼” (preferably ⅜”), use flathead screws on the bottom of the robot to ensure they do not get stuck, and don’t forget the wear and tear of wheels.
How-To_ Solder (Guidelines & Tips).txt:
How to solder

General guidelines

DO NOT FORGET HEAT SHRINK!!

The soldering iron should be between 550 and 600 degrees Fahrenheit (check your units!). Depending on how old/worn out the soldering tip is, you might need to go a bit higher, but you shouldn’t reach 700 degrees.

Use the solder sucker! It’ll keep the fumes out of your face so you don’t breathe them in. 

The key to soldering is holding your iron in one place and waiting. As solder melts, the surface tension will pull the solder towards itself and create a puddle that will be smooth when it melts. That’s how you get the nice shiny finish!



Wire to wire

Combine the wires: You know how in Avatar (the movie with the blue people) they do the hair thing that connects with other hair? That’s what you’re going to do—just like in the first picture, but make sure to press the wires down closer together. (If you have no idea what I’m talking about you may refer to this video for reference.) Alternatively, you can twist your wires together like they’re giving each other a hug, as seen in the second picture. 

		

Solder: Glob some solder on there. The more you can get in between the wire threads, the better. Try to make it as smooth as possible, if you can. 

Finish: If you don’t have any wires hanging out by themselves and if the wires don’t come apart when you pull them, then you’re probably good. 



Wire to XT60/MT60/MR30/MR60

Put heat shrink on your wire! 

Tin the wire: A good tinned wire should look like the one below (though I would strip the wire maybe half that amount). The biggest plus about tinning is it’ll keep the wire threads from fraying as you put the wire into the connector. A second plus about tinning is that when you heat the solder, you know the solder will already be at the end of the wire that you can’t reach once you’ve put the wire into the connector. Try to put enough solder on so it covers the outside and goes in between the threads a bit, but do not put too much solder on or else you won’t be able to fit it into the connector. 

		



Put the wire into the connector: Pretty self-explanatory. If it doesn’t fit, you’ve probably used too much solder. Use the desoldering tool to take some off. 

Solder: Feed the solder into the connector until the solder has basically filled the entire connector slot like a puddle. Ideally, this is what a perfect solder should look like:



The two wires should not touch each other at all.

Don’t forget heat shrink!



Wire to bullet connector

Tin the wire: See the second step of part C.

Put the wire into the connector. 

Solder: There’s a hole in the bullet connector through which you should feed the solder. Hold the iron up to the bullet connector to warm the metal, which should melt the solder that is tinned on your wire. The solder you add should melt upon touching the warm solder on your wire. 

		

Wire to power switch

sdfasd



Wire to ring connector

Put heat shrink on your wire! 

Strip the wire, and without tinning it, put the wire into the tube at the bottom of the ring connector, as seen in the pictures below. 

Important notes: Make sure you have the correct size ring connector for your wire gauge. Also, make sure your ring connector is not insulated (i.e. it should look like the picture below). 

You should see the wire poking out of the top, but it should not extend beyond the length of the tube. 

		

Crimp the ring connector to squish the tube around your wire. Some wire strippers have a crimper attached to it (see the picture below). 

		

Heat the outside of the tube and feed solder into the wire until it looks nice and smooth. 

Do the heat shrink stuff.

How-To_ Design a 4-bar Lifter.txt:
How to design a 4-bar lifter



A 4-bar lifter is an optimized type of lifter that allows the robot to lift both up and out. 







Why use a 4-bar lifter? 

This site has more information on why this type of lifter is good. 



Pros: 

A 4-bar linkage can be designed to push forward and up as it extends rather than drawing back and away from the opponent as it rises. 

The extension of the lifter arm can be tailored to keep a fairly constant load on the drive motor as it rises, reducing the motor torque requirement while increasing lift speed. 

The mechanism can be made very compact when retracted, so it can stay away from damage from your opponent's weapons but still able to extend to good height when needed.

Having a hard lower limit means that the lifter arm retracts into the same lowered position every time, so there is no need to manually "find" the lowest point as you would with a 360 degree flipper. 



Cons: 

A 4-bar lifter is more complex than a simple lifter mechanism. 

It is difficult to implement invertibility. 

It does not have 360 degrees of motion. 



How to design a 4-bar lifter

Use this calculator.
How-To_ Design a Drivetrain.txt:
How to design a drivetrain



This document covers: 

How to choose a design

Determining belt lengths

Designing drive pulleys

Choosing a drive motor and gearbox combo



Drive System Design Guide

Drive Calculation Spreadsheet: https://bit.ly/JustCuzDriveCalc

For the calculator you need to know the # of wheels, # of motors, wheel diameter, and motor specs

Main parameters that determine the needed motor/gearing

Weight class (how much weight can be dedicated to drive?)

Drive Strategy - control, wedge, or other?

Speed is actually a lower priority for a control bot than a vertical spinner - spinners need to achieve good bite and escape from a bad position

Pushing power/low end torque are critical for control bots, especially w/o wedges

Generally a wedge, lifter, grabber, or other control bot will want more drive power than a spinner

Determining how much drive power is needed is a function of the desired speed and torque for your chosen wheels

According to Ask Aaron’s drivetrain guidelines, you will want at least 1.5-2X the torque required to spin the robot wheels to prevent stalling/overloading the motor while pushing an opponent into or against a wall. 

Note: More torque with a reasonable top speed >> stupid fast top speed

Having the ability to go 100mph if you only have room to accelerate to 20mph means leaving lots of torque on the table

Combat arenas are small - acceleration and pushing power is often far more important than speed, and both are only related to torque and traction

Transferring Power to Wheels - Mechanics and Reductions

Direct drive:

Prosoften risky and fragile, but very simple; no external gearing

Supporting the other end of the axle is recommended - easy to destroy the motor with impacts

Basically just don't even think about it with an ungeared motor unless you have a very special circumstance (ultra low kV brushless yolodrive???)

Belt/chain drive

Simplest/easiest way to run 4WD off 2 motors, no tensioning needed if done properly

Generally easy to attach pulleys to a motor shaft

Typically can get no more than 3:1 per stage

Timing belts or chains are often best for 12lb and up as they won't slip, but round belts work great for smaller bots with lower torque

I managed to use O rings in place of welding my own PU belts in Draconid given sufficient stretch/tension, but this can be difficult to size properly

Note: all plain rubber belts lose significant tension over time

3D printing pulleys for belts works extremely well

Planetary Gearboxes - Pricey but compact and robust

Not good with impact loads, but often beefy output shafts that easily handle shear loads (best to support the axle if you can though)

Handle a ton of torque and very compact for the high ratios

Extremely expensive to get many P60s or Versas, expect $50-90 per drive side in a 12lb+ bot

Often needs an adapter to use brushless, but usually someone has done it before

Can drive a central pulley and belt to 4WD, or drive one wheel directly and belt to second for extra redundancy (see #5)

Gears

Metal gears are expensive but 3D printing is a great option (see Draconid)

Less impact tolerant than belts, but can be designed/made to spec

Pretty compact, but very restrictive on center-center

Unlike with pulleys/chains, it's not always possible to change ratios without changing center-center

3D printed herringbone gears have a larger root area, stronger tooth profile

Need 3 gears per side to reverse direction for 2 motor 4WD

Some guesswork can be involved in determining the width and pitch/module needed

Combinations of the above!

No harm in combining two different approaches, as long as you’re careful

Can get the best of both worlds by combining gears with belts/chains - high reduction with shock isolation

It can be much cheaper to replace a shaft and pulley than a two stage gearbox



Where to Buy Mechanical Components

You can buy Chain Sprockets, Gears, Pulleys, wheels and more at Andymark, Vex, ServoCity, McMaster, and more!

P60/P80/P61 gearboxes are at Banebots, and Versaplanetary is Vex. 

Wheels are available from tons of hobby stores, Amazon, Fingertech, Robotshop, several of the above vendors, etc. 

Also take a look on Ebay, Banggood, or other Chinese retailers but YMMV

Brushless motors are available on Amazon, Hobbyking, Banggood, and any drone/RC hobby store

Wheels, wheels, wheels!

Softer rubber is more grippy but less durable

Foam tires are able to take direct hits without trashing your bot unlike rubber (see: D2 kit wheels, Fingertech wheels, lite flights)

Custom silicone cast tires are soft and grippy and often the best performing, but require a lot of experimentation, which means a lot of $$$ and time

Be sure to think about how to actually transmit torque to the wheels

Live shaft turning with the wheel

Set screws on flats (Fingertech hubs)

Keyed hubs (Banebots and similar, common for larger bots)

D or Hex shaft/bore, or spline (also Banebots, VEX stuff, Servocity hubs)

Dead shaft - axle doesn’t spin

Bolt through to pulley/gear (Conduit)

Custom 3D printed things (Draconid)



Sources:

Team Tentacle torque Calculator: http://runamok.tech/squid/newtorquecalc.htm

AskAaron Drivetrain Gear Ratios Article: http://runamok.tech/AskAaron/optimum.html

Brushless motor torque estimation article

How to bind receivers to transmitters

FRSky Taranis X-Lite S

Start with the receiver connected to the battery but TURNED OFF

Go to the SETUP screen





Scroll down to Module

Select [Reg]





While the transmitter displays this screen, turn on the receiver WHILE holding down the button on the receiver





The screen should display a “Registration OK” message

Press [ENTER]

Power off the receiver

Scroll to Receiver 1

Power the receiver

How-To_ Use the Bambu 3D printer.txt:
How To Use The Bambu 3D Printer

Getting Started

Software

Download Bambu studio app: https://bambulab.com/en/download/studio

Download it on your phone too! It’s very helpful

Sign in to CRC on Bambu Studio

Username: combatrobotics@cornell.edu

Password: coolR0bots13!

In Fusion360, save the part you want to print as .step file (make sure it is NOT hidden)

If it's a component in a multi-component file:

Right click on component → export → select .step as the filetype

NAME THE EXPORT NICELY!

Include the name of the file it's from and the current version number of the file. 

If it's a single-component file:

File → export → select .step as filetype

The filename should automatically have the version number

Import .step file into Bambu Studio

Enable supports if necessary (see the “Print Details” section for more information.)

Located in the ‘Supports’ tab

Tree style supports are great if you want them to be easier to remove

Change plate to match plate in printer

Slice your part

If you print and receive the error message “print settings incompatible,” check the nozzle type and make sure it is X1 carbon

After following all hardware steps, Print Plate.



	Hardware

Log into printer

If you’re not logged in already, scan QR code in the app

In the app, it’s under the ‘Me’ tab in top right corner next to the bell

Change Filament

Go to ‘Filament’ tab on printer

Hit the unspool button (or something along those lines)

Follow the instructions on the printer (just pull the spool off and pull it out of the tube) 

If the old filament prints something while clearing out then use pliers to take it out

Mount new filament where the old filament was.

Feed filament through the tube as much as you can.

Make sure that the filament is also fed through the little hole on the spool, as seen in the picture below. This prevents the filament from getting tangled.

		

Hit the “put in new filament” button on printer (or something along those lines)

Follow the instructions on the printer

If it's not sensing anything, push the filament into the tube more

Change plate to match filament

Each physical plate has the description of what materials you can print on it.

Plates can be cleaned in the bathroom with hand soap every so often.

Remember that the plates are double sided! The back of the plate is a different material than the front of the plate.

Use a glue stick on the plate to help the print stick better.

A consistent, thin layer is best; you can put it everywhere on the plate.

If the plate already has glue, it's okay to add more!



Cleaning the 3D Printer

someone fill this i

Print Details

	Printing Everyday Objects/Not Structurally Important Robot Parts

For the vast majority of projects, settings don’t matter beyond % Infill, which should be set to 15%, and Support Type, which should be set to either Auto or Auto Tree.

However, make sure the filament and plate type match what material you’re using to print!



Robot Parts/Structurally Important Materials:

Infill: This is usually reliable at 15%, however can be adjusted to be higher if needed. This is where most of the weight will come from on components. This is useful with TPU, which has a variable flexibility based on how much infill there is.

Walls: Walls are the number of layers between anything touching open air and infill. This is useful to provide a good amount of material for plastite screws to grip in, or to protect the most vulnerable to contact portions of the part.

Profiles: If trying to get a durable part which can hold up under high loads or impacts, selecting Strength Profile will help immensely. Otherwise, Standard profiles will serve just fine.

Common Issues

The Filament Isn’t Extruding!

Cause: Filament residue or metal fragments are caught in the extruder.

Explanation: The 3D printer is not a perfect system, and because the hot end, or the part where the filament comes out, has such a small hole, residual fragments of filament, or other debris, can clog the hole.

Solution:

Remove the filament from the 3D printer.

Take off the front of the cube that holds the extruder and hot end. It should be held on only by a few magnets.

Use an allen key to remove the two screws which hold the hot end onto the rest of the printer. Do not detach any of the cables.

Use an allen key to remove the fan which is attached to the side of the hot end. Normally, this fan cools the hot end down. Detach the cable which connects the fan to the rest of the printer.

Put on gloves, and turn on the printer and heat the hot end to 250 degrees. This will begin melting any stuck plastic in the printer.

Using the long, thin needle that comes with the printer, or any needle smaller than the diameter of the opening of the hot end (Typically .4 mm), begin poking through both ends of the hot end to remove any debris.

I’ve found the most effective way to be to poke from the end where the filament is extruded from, and stick it as far through as possible.

Repeat Step 6 until debris cleared and needle has no trace of residue.

Reassemble the printer following the above steps in reverse.

NOTE: If printer is still malfunctioning, the hot end may be too clogged to easily remove debris. In this case, repeat the above steps with a new hot end assembly.

Resources:

https://wiki.bambulab.com/en/x1/maintenance/replace-complete-hotend



The Yellow Gear is Clicking and not Spinning!

Cause: Hot end or extruder may be jammed, or filament spool may be caught.

Explanation: The yellow gear you can see on the side of the printer head is part of the component which pushes filament through the printer, called the extruder. For a variety of reasons, this gear can get stuck or jammed, and when it clicks and doesn’t move, this can often be your first indication that extruding is failing.

Solution:

Remove filament from the printer.

NOTE: This may not work with just pressing the unload filament button on the printer. If so, try manually removing the filament by pressing in the lever on the side of the printer to cut the filament, and pressing down on the part where the tubing meets the printer head to release the tubing. Throughout this process, you may be able to remove the filament from the printer by pulling manually.

Take off the front of the cube that holds the extruder and hot end. It should be held on only by a few magnets.

Use an allen key to remove the two screws which hold the hot end onto the rest of the printer. Do not detach any of the cables.

At this point, you may observe the top of the hot end is clogged by a cut piece of filament. If this is the case, follow the instructions above.

If this is not the case, follow the instructions below.

Use an allen key to remove the extruder assembly from the printer head. This will be the part directly above where the hot end was. You may now detach the cables which connect the hot end to the printer head.

Now with the completely removed extruder, begin disassembling the extruder by removing the plate held on by four screws.

Continue manually disassembling the extruder until a blockage is uncovered.

Reassemble extruder and reconnect printer by following the above instructions.

NOTE: If problem persists, the extruder may be 

Resources:

https://wiki.bambulab.com/en/P1/maintenance/extruder-cleaning-guide

https://forum.bambulab.com/t/filament-broken-in-extruder/35553



The Filament Cutter isn’t Cutting/Is Repeatedly Clicking Or Getting Stuck!

Cause: Something is likely jammed in the extruder or is making the extruder not work properly

Explanation: The filament cutter is what cuts the filament so you can remove old filament and put in new filament. Sometimes, debris or filament gets caught in the extruder, which prevents the filament cutter from functioning properly.

Solution:

Follow above steps to disassemble extruder assembly fully.



I Can’t Load Filament!

Cause: Filament tubing improperly aligned/attached to printer head, or skill issue.

Explanation: The clear white tubing is what guides the filament into the printer head from the spool. Occasionally, this will get out of alignment/lose connection to the printer head, which can make loading filament difficult. Occasionally, this can also be a symptom of the above three issues.

Solution:

Remove faceplate from printer head. This should only be held on by a few magnets.

Depress the circular plunger where the tubing/filament enters the top of the printer head. If the tubing is attached, this should release the tubing.

Try loading the filament without the tubing. If this works as expected, depress the plunger again to reattach the tubing.

NOTE: If this step fails, examine the above instructions for a clogged extruder.

Reassemble printer following above instructions in reverse.
How-To_ Set Up a Raspberry Pi.txt:
Setting up Raspberry Pi on a newly bought Pi

Flashing (for a brand new Pi) 

If newly bought, the Pi is just empty, so you need to download the OS to start using it:

Get an adapter that can connect the SD card (typically an empty one)  to the desired device 

Download the Raspberry Pi Imager OS (official website) 

The screen should appear then Select the device and the image model 

The image model could be either from an SD card that was stored on your computer or the following OS provided 



Once you have selected the options, press next and wait for the imager to finish writing 

Once completed, remove the SD card and put it into the desired Raspberry Pi then plug in the power supply

The Pi should be on and would need to be hooked up to a monitor (needs a dongle for HDMI), mouse and keyboard

Pi should start booting up and display on the screen 

YAY, you successfully started up a Pi now go be a menace 

Imagining and Writing 

Similar to copying the information from a previous SD (imaging), which can either be pasted on a

new or used pi (writing) 



Imagining (either from a previous or new Pi) 

Reading (for Windows)

Take the SD card from a current pi and connect it to your laptop 

Download the Win32DiskImager

The following page should show up

(To confirm if the SD is in, under “device” it should show random symbols)

 

Select the folder button in the “image file” box, create a file, and save

Return to the page and select “Read”

Estimated time should take within minutes or less than an hour 

*if hour >1 select cancel, issue I’m not sure of (ask Sebastian) 



Writing (Putting information from a previous SD onto a new SD card) 

Follow the “Imaging” direction to have the copy of the previous SD card file that you want to have write on a new SD

Take the new SD you want to write over and plug it into the computer with the file

Open Win32DiskImager 

In the “Image File” click the folder icon and select the Image of the previous SD 

Select “Write” to start copying over the information to the new SD

Once the file is complete you have identical SD cards and you can use it how you see fit, Yay!



Software Configuration for Remote Access

On-board Pi Information

Connect the Pi to a monitor, keyboard, and mouse

Connect the Pi to the RedRover network (more steps involved, but I forgot, sorry -Ethan)

After connecting successfully to the network, the IP address will pop up briefly

Otherwise, to access the IP address:

Open the terminal

Type ifconfig

You should see a terminal output with three sections; under the last section, labelled wlan0, write down the IP address following inet, which should have the form xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx

In the terminal, type sudo raspi-config

Navigate to “Interface Options”, then “VNC”, and press “Yes” to enable VNC.



On Your Computer: Windows

On your computer now, be sure you have RealVNC installed

RealVNC might prompt you to make an account; simply continue to the account creation, then press cancel

In the top bar, enter the IP address previously saved

When prompted, use the current Raspberry Pi credentials to sign into the Pi

NOTE: Although multiple users can connect to the Pi remotely, they are all functionally controlling the same computer; thus, operations performed by one user will be reflected across all connected devices.

NOTE: The IP address is also liable to change after turning off and on again, so if connection fails, double check you have the right IP address
